awd_titl_txt: Assessing student attentional engagement from brain activity during STEM instruction
awd_abstract_narration:
When a teacher is presenting new material during class or online, are students actually paying attention? The ambitious goal of this project is to objectively measure students' attentional engagement during learning using electroencephalography (EEG). Specifically, it measures students' brain activity as they watch online educational videos, and then compares their neural activity to how well they perform on traditional measures of learning such as tests and quizzes. If successful, this project will develop a tool that can assess student attentional engagement at the neural level and predict learning performance. Providing a concrete and practical educational application for brain imaging is important because it can be used to inform the effectiveness of teaching approaches and instructional materials, or intervene in real-time when individual students fail to engage with the material. Such a tool may be particularly important in the context of online education where teachers and students often do not immediately interact with one another. The educational video material will focus on natural sciences and math with the goal of improving STEM education. The project is funded by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program which funds basic research that seeks to understand, build theory to explain, and suggest interventions (and innovations) to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning, and participation. It is co-funded by the Perception, Action, and Cognition program in the Social, Behavioral, and  Economics Sciences Directorate. 

Effective learning requires attention to the instructional material. By measuring attention from brain signals, both the efficacy of instruction and the performance of individual students may be assessed. Knowing whether and when students fail to engage attention is crucial for designing better instructional materials or to assist students on an individual basis. The basic hypothesis of this project is that effective instructional materials will generate similar EEG responses across attentive students. The investigators test this hypothesis for STEM educational videos to determine if learning can indeed be predicted.  Participants include ~180 undergraduates enrolled in City College of New York's Division of Science and School of Engineering. Educationally, participants also include 30 high school seniors from four diverse New York City high schools.  Similarity among students' responses to educational video will be measured as inter-subject correlation (ISC) of EEG activity. The project has three specific aims: (1) Validate ISC using instructional videos; (2) Test the link between ISC and traditional learning outcome measures; and (3) Develop a mobile application to help transfer ISC measures from the laboratory to the classroom setting.

por.por_cntn:
Effective learning requires attention to the instructional material. Knowing whether and when students fail to engage attention is crucial for designing better instructional materials or to assist students on an individual basis. Recent progress in neuroscience suggests that attention to video can be measured by recording neural activity in the viewer. The basic hypothesis of this project was that effective instructional video will generate similar neural signals across attentive students. We tested this hypothesis for STEM educational videos and determined if learning performance can indeed be predicted from this measure of attention. In an effort to find more practical signals to accomplish the same we also explored eye gaze position and other physiological signals. We conducted a series of laboratory and online experiments totalling a large number of participants (around 200 in the laboratory and around 1000 online). 

 

Results: 

  • Our main objective was to validate inter-subject correlation (ISC) of electroencephalographic (EEG) signals as a metric of attention for instructional video. We conducted a series of laboratory experiments with STEM videos readily available online. ISC of EEG was strongly modulated by attention and was predictive of test taking performance about the material presented in the video. This was true for different video styles,  and comprehension and memory questions alike.

  • In an effort to provide a more practical method to measure attention, we used eye gaze position. We found that the ISC of gaze position is high among attentive students and ISC is predictive of test-taking performance. These results were validated with remote video using conventional web cameras suggesting that this could be implemented online at scale. The experiments we conducted included up to 1000 participants online.

  • Surprisingly, we also discovered that the ISC of instantaneous heart rate and other physiological signals are also modulated by attention, even when the information is presented only as an audio narrative. This has wide ranging implications beyond education as was discussed in a number of media reports that were prompted by this discovery. 

 

Broader Impacts

 

The project provided an opportunity to participate in cognitive neuroscience research for a number of highschool and undergraduate students from New York City with a diverse background. Students collected physiological data, assisted in selective educational videos and designing questions, and assisted in labeling the video material. Several undergraduate students participated in coding of data analysis using modern machine learning techniques. 

 

The project engaged with stakeholders in the EdTech and entertainment community to explore implications of this research to online education and beyond. 

 

Significant publications and dissemination:

  • Jens Madsen, Maximilian Nentwich, Lucas C. Parra, How to measure and improve attention in remote video-based learning, International Mind, Brain and Education Society Conference 2022, Montreal, Canada, July 21-23, 2022. (best poster award) 

  • Jens Madsen, Lucas C Parra, "Cognitive processing of a common stimulus synchronizes brains, hearts, and eyes", PNAS Nexus, March 10, 2022.

  • Pauline Perez*, Jens Madsen*, Leah Banellis, Basak Turker, Federico Raimondo, Vincent Perlbarg, Melanie Valente, Marie-Cecile Nierat, Louis Puybasset, Lionel Naccache, Thomas Similowski, Damian Cruse, Lucas C. Parra, Jacobo D. Sitt, "Conscious processing of narrative stimuli synchronizes heart rate between individuals", Cell Reports, September 14 2021, Vol. 36, 11 

  • Jens Madsen, Sara U. Julio, Pawel J. Gucik, Richard Steinberg, and Lucas C. Parra, "Synchronized eye movements predict test scores in online video education", Proceedings of National Academy of Science (PNAS), February 2, 2021 118 (5) e2016980118

  • Jens Madsen, Margulis EH, Simchy-Gross R, Parra LC. Music synchronizes brainwaves across listeners with strong effects of repetition, familiarity and training. Scientific Reports. 2019 Mar 5;9(1):3576.

  •  Samantha S. Cohen*, Jens Madsen*, Touchan G, Robles D, Lima SF, Henin S, Parra LC. Neural engagement with online educational videos predicts learning performance for individual students. Neurobiology of learning and memory. 2018 Nov 1;155:60-4.
